awd_titl_txt: Detection of Sunlight-induced Thymine Dimers in Sea         Surface Microbial Communities
awd_abstract_narration: Stratospheric ozone depletion in polar regions is of scientific                 and public concern because ozone absorbs ultraviolet radiation                  from the sun.  UV-radiation causes DNA damage.  Dr. Yayanos                     proposes to quantify the effects of increased solar UV-radiation                at the sea surface.  He will develop methods to measure the                     amount of thymine dimers, one of the main photoproducts formed in               DNA, in sea surface microbial communities. In addition, attempts                will be made to show that there is a variation in the level of                  thymine dimers on a diel basis.  The concentration level of                     thymine dimers in the sea surface microbial community may be                    useful in developing a global model of ecosystem damage resulting               from stratospheric ozone depletion.  Furthermore, if the high                   performance liquid chromatograph method or the method based on                  DNA processing enzymes works for detecting thymine dimers, then                 it would allow for the search for thymine dimers buried over                    geological time in sediments  and in ice.  The pilot studies                    proposed will be conducted on samples collected from southern                   California coastal waters.

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography
